results.title: Babar. Story of Babar the little elephant. Babar comes to America.
results.creator_credit: Nelvana, Lee Mendelson, Bill Melendez and Ed Levitt
results.brief_description: Narrated by Peter Ustinov and based on the Brunhoff books about Babar the King of the Elephants. “Story of Babar the little elephant” introduces us to Babar. After his mother is shot by hunters he runs away to Paris where he is adopted by a kind little old lady. Although he loves her he misses the jungle and returns home where he is crowned King of the Elephants and marries his true love, Celeste. Based on “The Travels of Babar” and “Babar comes to America” episode two follows Babar and Celeste as they travel first by balloon, then whale and ship to America where they become movie stars.

results.title: Babar. School days; King Tuttle's vote
results.creator_credit: Nelvana, Ellipse, Michael Hirsh, Patrick Loubert, Clive A Smith and Laura Shepherd
results.brief_description: Two adventures of Babar the elephant. “School Days”. When Babar’s son Alexander is upset because “he wants to be like the other kids”, Babar tells him about his own time at school. The school bullies, Marcel and Maurice pick on his trunk but Babar has the last laugh. “King Tuttle’s vote” King Tuttle’s vote is needed to stop the Rataxes from polluting Lake Celestine. He is “kingnapped” by them, however Babar and his friends save both King Tuttle and the lake. Adapted from the stories of Jean and Laurent de Brunhoff.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Nelvana, Ellipse, Michael Hirsh, Patrick Loubert, Clive A Smith and Laura Shepherd

results.title: Babar. Race to the Moon; No Place Like Home
results.creator_credit: Nelvana, Clifford Ross Co, Michael Hirsh, Patrick Loubert, Clive A Smith and Laura Shepherd
results.brief_description: More trouble with Lord Rataxes awaits King Babar in these two adventures in Elephant land: “Race to the Moon” - Babar’s hopes of rebuilding an old theatre are jeopardised when all his subjects get caught up in trying to build a rocket ship to beat Lord Rataxes to the moon. “No Place Like Home” - Babar lets a young circus boy live in the palace. But when the lad wants to return to his circus home, he discovers that it might be too late, because the circus has been captured by Lord Rataxes. Based on the picture books by Jean and Laurent de Brunhoff.

results.title: Babar. Elephant's best friend; The Show must go on
results.creator_credit: Nelvana, Ellipse, Michael Hirsh, Patrick Loubert, Clive A Smith and Laura Shepherd
results.brief_description: Join Babar in two more delightful episodes: 1. “An Elephant’s Best Friend” - Lord Rataxes stops all pomegranate shipments from reaching Celesteville, but when Babar calls on the help of a warthog, Rataxes is suddenly willing to talk. 2. “The Show Must Go On” - Babar organises a world-class ballet to be performed in Celesteville, but the star of the show, a temperamental prima ballerina, causes problems for cast and crew. Based on the books by Jean and Laurent de Brunhoff.

results.title: Babar. Babar's Triumph
results.creator_credit: Nelvana, Clifford Ross Co, Michael Hirsh, Patrick Loubert, Clive A Smith and Laura Shepherd
results.brief_description: Two stories: “Babar’s triumph” and “Babar’s choice”. “Babar’s triumph”: Babar faces his greatest challenge when the Hunter returns to threaten his kingdom. He must unite Lord Rataxes and everyone in the jungle to fight the Hunter and repel him once and for all. “Babar’s choice”: Babar’s advisers, Cornelius and Pompadour, jeopardise his relationship with Celeste by insisting that he take the Gorilla King’s daughter to an important palace ball instead of Celeste. Based on the picture books by Jean and Laurent de Brunhoff.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Nelvana, Clifford Ross Co, Michael Hirsh, Patrick Loubert, Clive A Smith and Laura Shepherd

results.title: Babar. Babar's First Step. City Ways. (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Nelvana, Clifford Ross Co, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, Michael Hirsh, Patrick Loubert, Clive A Smith and Raymond Jafelice
results.brief_description: Animated versions of two stories about Babar, King of the Elephants. “Babar’s first step” tells how Babar’s mother was killed by a hunter when he was very young leaving Babar to cope on his own. “City ways” tells how he fled to the city which he found dangerous and confusing until an old lady tried to teach him how to fit into her world. Adapted from the picture books by Jean and Laurent de Brunhoff.

results.title: Babar and Father Christmas
results.brief_description: In this delightful, fully animated tale, King Babar takes a journey in search of the legendary Father Christmas. But lurking along on Babar’s trail is Babar’s arch-enemy, Rataxes the Rhinoceros, who wants all of Santa’s toys for himself. Based on the book by Jean de Brunhoff and narrated by Laurent de Brunhoff. Rated: G

results.title: Babar's First Step
results.creator_credit: Michael Hirsh, Patricia Loubert, Clive A Smith and Raymond Jafelice
results.brief_description: Babar’s First Steps - Babar leads a happy and carefree life with his mother and all the other elephants in the jungle. But his life is shortened when a Hunter kills his mother and Babar must cope on his own. “City Ways” - Forced to run away from the jungle by the Hunter, Babar makes his way to the city, only to find it very dangerous and confusing. He is befriended by the Old Lady, who tries to teach him how to fit into her world. Rated: G

results.title: BabaKiueria = Barbeque area [DVD] (A)
results.creator_credit: Julian Pringle, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Don Featherstone and Geoffrey Atherden
results.brief_description:
‘BabaKiueria’ takes a satirical look at black-white relations in late twentieth century Australia, with a comic depiction of a racial role reversal. In documentary (or ‘mockumentary’) style, the film’s presenter investigates white lives in the fictitious land of ‘BabaKiueria’ (‘Barbeque Area’), where white people are a minority, living under black laws and suffering from discriminatory practices and attitudes held by the black majority. Written by Geoffrey Atherden (‘Mother and Son’, ‘Grass Roots’), the film was awarded a United Nations Media Peace Prize in 1987.
Stars Michelle Torres, Bob Maza, Kevin Smith, Cecily Polson, Tony Barry.
